bibl.title: Letter from Walter Reed to James Carroll, February 16, 1901

div1.p: Reed arrives in Washington. He discusses an article for the Journal of the American Medical Association and comments on the editor's changes. No promotion for Carroll is forthcoming.

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to James Carroll, February 16, 1901
div1.opener:
H
From His pencil Letter
Went over & lectured
to the class last
night. We are studying
the lung.
War Department
Surgeon General's Office
Army Medical Museum and Library
Washington
Feb. 16, 1901
Dr. James Carroll
U. S. Army
Columbia Barracks
Quemados, Cuba
My dear Doctor:
div1.p:
I have been trying to get a chance to write to you ever since I
landed here last Tuesday night at 815 pm o'clock. Of course, I was
delighted to get your cable gram telling me that the 57 day old
bird had brought Hanberry down & that the 16 day insect had been a
success with Sontag. I hope that Dr. Ames got Weatherwax to submit.
If so, I prognosticate a failure, as I am inclined to think that he
has already had a very mild attack. If he should be brought down
by insects 63 days old, it would be worth hearing of. Our article
appears in the Journal of the American Medical Association which
arrived today. I corrected the proof & sent it back promptly but of
course in order to “scoop” all other journals he didn't wait for the
corrected proof - not only that, the damned rascal took lots of
liberty with our ms, such as wiping out the three sectons into
which we had naturally divided the article & put instead his
own asinine head-lines! I swore a blue streak & shall cuss him
out by letter, but the damage is done - so much for sending the
article to a yellow medical journal! I am trying to save the 500
reprints from his damnable stupidity, and hope to do so. I am very
sorry to have to tell you that you need not look for any promotion
as the Secretary refused to fill any vacancies caused by Major
Kean or other vacancies under that particular act -- only appointments
will be made for Philippine service. It would be folly for you to
do this. The general recommended you to fill Kean's vacancy.
Weather here damnable until today. I have been swathed in flannels
and overcoats until I am nearly dead. Almost wish thot that I was back
in Cuba. Of course, I have been put on the Examining Board which
meets Monday. Much love to the Kean's & Starks. Kindest regards to
Ames & the others. Come back as soon as you can.
